nexttext:
where $G$ and $\gamma_{A}$ are the gravitational constant in the bulk and the $(d-1)$-minimal surface extended into the bulk with the same boundary $\partial A$ of subsystem $A$, respectively. Recently, the behavior of entanglement entropy for holographic superconductor models have been studied in investigating conductor/superconductor phase transitions \cite{r3,r4}.  We also obtained an exact form of the holographic entropy due to an 
advantage of approximate solutions inside normal and superconducting phases with backreactions for 2D holographic superconductors \cite{Momeni:2015iea}. 

Recently, Susskind has found a new quantity releted to {\it complexity}  in CFTs which is dual to a volume of a codimension one time slice in anti-de Sitter (AdS) \cite{Susskind:2014rva1,Susskind:2014rva2}. The time slice connect two boundaries dual to the thermofield doubled CFTs, through the Einstein-Rosen bridge \cite{Stanford:2014jda}. Following Refs. \cite{Susskind:2014rva1,Susskind:2014rva2}, the holographic complexity can be defined as:

prevtext:
where $G$ and $\gamma_{A}$ are the gravitational constant in the bulk and the $(d-1)$-minimal surface extended into the bulk with the same boundary $\partial A$ of subsystem $A$, respectively. Recently, the behavior of entanglement entropy for holographic superconductor models have been studied in investigating conductor/superconductor phase transitions \cite{r3,r4}.  We also obtained an exact form of the holographic entropy due to an 
advantage of approximate solutions inside normal and superconducting phases with backreactions for 2D holographic superconductors \cite{Momeni:2015iea}. 

Recently, Susskind has found a new quantity releted to {\it complexity}  in CFTs which is dual to a volume of a codimension one time slice in anti-de Sitter (AdS) \cite{Susskind:2014rva1,Susskind:2014rva2}. The time slice connect two boundaries dual to the thermofield doubled CFTs, through the Einstein-Rosen bridge \cite{Stanford:2014jda}. Following Refs. \cite{Susskind:2014rva1,Susskind:2014rva2}, the holographic complexity can be defined as:

mathml:
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E4.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="x=l\int\frac{dz}{\sqrt{z_{*}^{2}-z^{2}}\sqrt{f_{0}(z)}}-\frac{\epsilon^{2}l}{2%
}\int\frac{f_{2}(z)dz}{\sqrt{z_{*}^{2}-z^{2}}f_{0}(z)^{3/2}}" display="block"><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mrow><mrow><mi>l</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo largeop="true" symmetric="true">∫</mo><mfrac><mrow><mi>d</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>z</mi></mrow><mrow><msqrt><mrow><msubsup><mi>z</mi><mo>*</mo><mn>2</mn></msubsup><mo>-</mo><msup><mi>z</mi><mn>2</mn></msup></mrow></msqrt><mo>⁢</mo><msqrt><mrow><msub><mi>f</mi><mn>0</mn></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>z</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></msqrt></mrow></mfrac></mrow></mrow><mo>-</mo><mrow><mfrac><mrow><msup><mi>ϵ</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>⁢</mo><mi>l</mi></mrow><mn>2</mn></mfrac><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo largeop="true" symmetric="true">∫</mo><mfrac><mrow><msub><mi>f</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>z</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><mi>d</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>z</mi></mrow><mrow><msqrt><mrow><msubsup><mi>z</mi><mo>*</mo><mn>2</mn></msubsup><mo>-</mo><msup><mi>z</mi><mn>2</mn></msup></mrow></msqrt><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mi>f</mi><mn>0</mn></msub><mo>⁢</mo><msup><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>z</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn><mo>/</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup></mrow></mfrac></mrow></mrow></mrow></mrow></math>

nexttext: is the Log-integral which satisfies the following recursion relation.
mathml: <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E5.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="L(M||N)\equiv\int z^{M}(\log z)^{N}dz" display="block"><mrow><mi>L</mi><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>M</mi><mo stretchy="false">|</mo><mo stretchy="false">|</mo><mi>N</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo>≡</mo><mo largeop="true" symmetric="true">∫</mo><msup><mi>z</mi><mi>M</mi></msup><msup><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>log</mi><mi>z</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mi>N</mi></msup><mi>d</mi><mi>z</mi></mrow></math>

nexttext:
On the other hand, we can employ the "Domain Wall" method in calculating holographic complexity.
Domain wall approach was
proposed to investigate some aspects of the holographic entanglement entropy along renormalization
group (RG) trajectories \cite{Albash2012}.
Thus the expression for holographic complexity (\ref{V}) can be written in the below form:
prevtext: is the Log-integral which satisfies the following recursion relation.
mathml: <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E6.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="(M+1)L(M||N)+NL(M||N-1)=z^{M+1}(\log z)^{N}" display="block"><mrow><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>M</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>1</mn><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mi>L</mi><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>M</mi><mo stretchy="false">|</mo><mo stretchy="false">|</mo><mi>N</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo>+</mo><mi>N</mi><mi>L</mi><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>M</mi><mo stretchy="false">|</mo><mo stretchy="false">|</mo><mi>N</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>1</mn><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><msup><mi>z</mi><mrow><mi>M</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></msup><msup><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>log</mi><mi>z</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mi>N</mi></msup></mrow></math>

prevtext:
On the other hand, we can employ the "Domain Wall" method in calculating holographic complexity.
Domain wall approach was
proposed to investigate some aspects of the holographic entanglement entropy along renormalization
group (RG) trajectories \cite{Albash2012}.
Thus the expression for holographic complexity (\ref{V}) can be written in the below form:
mathml:
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E7.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="V(\gamma)=\frac{r_{+}^{2}}{l}\Big{(}\int_{z_{*}}^{z_{DW}}\frac{x(z)dz}{z^{3}%
\sqrt{f(z)}}+\int_{z_{DW}}^{z_{UV}}\frac{x(z)dz}{z^{3}\sqrt{f(z)}}\Big{)}." display="block"><mrow><mrow><mrow><mi>V</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>γ</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><mfrac><msubsup><mi>r</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>2</mn></msubsup><mi>l</mi></mfrac><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo maxsize="160%" minsize="160%">(</mo><mrow><mrow><msubsup><mo largeop="true" symmetric="true">∫</mo><msub><mi>z</mi><mo>*</mo></msub><msub><mi>z</mi><mrow><mi>D</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>W</mi></mrow></msub></msubsup><mfrac><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>z</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><mi>d</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>z</mi></mrow><mrow><msup><mi>z</mi><mn>3</mn></msup><mo>⁢</mo><msqrt><mrow><mi>f</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>z</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></msqrt></mrow></mfrac></mrow><mo>+</mo><mrow><msubsup><mo largeop="true" symmetric="true">∫</mo><msub><mi>z</mi><mrow><mi>D</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>W</mi></mrow></msub><msub><mi>z</mi><mrow><mi>U</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>V</mi></mrow></msub></msubsup><mfrac><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>z</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><mi>d</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>z</mi></mrow><mrow><msup><mi>z</mi><mn>3</mn></msup><mo>⁢</mo><msqrt><mrow><mi>f</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>z</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></msqrt></mrow></mfrac></mrow></mrow><mo maxsize="160%" minsize="160%">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>.</mo></mrow></math>

nexttext:
\end{widetext}
where coefficients can be defined as:
mathml:
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E8.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="V(\gamma)=\frac{r_{+}^{2}}{l^{2}}\sum_{n=0}^{\infty}\sum_{m=0}^{\infty}\sum_{%
\alpha,\beta=1/2,3/2}D_{n}^{\alpha}D_{m}^{\beta}\Big{(}K_{nm}^{\alpha\beta}(z_%
{*},z_{DW})+K_{nm}^{\alpha\beta}(z_{DW},z_{UV})\Big{)}" display="block"><mrow><mrow><mi>V</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>γ</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><mfrac><msubsup><mi>r</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>2</mn></msubsup><msup><mi>l</mi><mn>2</mn></msup></mfrac><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><munderover><mo largeop="true" movablelimits="false" symmetric="true">∑</mo><mrow><mi>n</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">∞</mi></munderover><mrow><munderover><mo largeop="true" movablelimits="false" symmetric="true">∑</mo><mrow><mi>m</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">∞</mi></munderover><mrow><munder><mo largeop="true" movablelimits="false" symmetric="true">∑</mo><mrow><mrow><mrow><mi>α</mi><mo>,</mo><mi>β</mi></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><mn>1</mn><mo>/</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow></mrow><mo>,</mo><mrow><mn>3</mn><mo>/</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow></mrow></munder><mrow><msubsup><mi>D</mi><mi>n</mi><mi>α</mi></msubsup><mo>⁢</mo><msubsup><mi>D</mi><mi>m</mi><mi>β</mi></msubsup><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo maxsize="160%" minsize="160%">(</mo><mrow><mrow><msubsup><mi>K</mi><mrow><mi>n</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>m</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>α</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>β</mi></mrow></msubsup><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><msub><mi>z</mi><mo>*</mo></msub><mo>,</mo><msub><mi>z</mi><mrow><mi>D</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>W</mi></mrow></msub><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>+</mo><mrow><msubsup><mi>K</mi><mrow><mi>n</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>m</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>α</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>β</mi></mrow></msubsup><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><msub><mi>z</mi><mrow><mi>D</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>W</mi></mrow></msub><mo>,</mo><msub><mi>z</mi><mrow><mi>U</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>V</mi></mrow></msub><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo maxsize="160%" minsize="160%">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow></mrow></mrow></mrow></mrow></math>

 in terms of the temperature $T$, critical parameters like $T_c$, $\mu_c$ and dual quantity as $\mu$. Note that from the coherence length near $T_{c}$ behaves as:

mathml:
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E11.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="T\approx T_{0}\Big{[}1-\frac{{\epsilon}^{2}}{4}\,{\frac{\left(2\,\pi\,\beta_{{%

_{z=1}\Big{]}" display="block"><mrow><mi>T</mi><mo>≈</mo><mrow><msub><mi>T</mi><mn>0</mn></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo maxsize="160%" minsize="160%">[</mo><mrow><mn>1</mn><mo>-</mo><msub><mrow><mrow><mpadded width="+1.7pt"><mfrac><msup><mi>ϵ</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mn>4</mn></mfrac></mpadded><mo>⁢</mo><mfrac><mrow><mo>(</mo><mrow><mrow><mpadded width="+1.7pt"><mn>2</mn></mpadded><mo>⁢</mo><mpadded width="+1.7pt"><mi>π</mi></mpadded><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mi>β</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>z</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>+</mo><mrow><msub><mi>r</mi><mo>+</mo></msub><mo>⁢</mo><msubsup><mi>f</mi><mn>2</mn><mo>′</mo></msubsup><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>z</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><msubsup><mi>T</mi><mn>0</mn><mrow><mo>-</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></msubsup></mrow></mrow><mo>)</mo></mrow><mi>π</mi></mfrac></mrow><mo fence="true" stretchy="false">|</mo></mrow><mrow><mi>z</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></msub></mrow><mo maxsize="160%" minsize="160%">]</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow></math>

prevtext: where $T_0=\frac{f_0'(r_{+})}{4\pi}$ is Hawking temperature for pure BTZ black hole.  When $\mu_0=\mu_c$, the above Hawking temperature tends to the critical point $T_c$ where the order $\epsilon^2\to0$. By putting the $f_2(z)$ (Eq. (\ref{f2})) and
mathml:
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E12.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\beta_{2}(z)=-16\kappa^{2}\int z^{3}dz\Big{(}1-\frac{l^{4}z^{2}\mu^{2}r_{+}^{2%
}\ln(\frac{z}{r_{+}})^{2}}{4\Big{(}\kappa^{2}\mu^{2}\ln(\frac{z}{r_{+}})+r_{+}%
^{2}(1-z^{2})\Big{)}^{2}}\Big{)}" display="block"><mrow><mrow><msub><mi>β</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>z</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><mo>-</mo><mrow><mn>16</mn><mo>⁢</mo><msup><mi>κ</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo largeop="true" symmetric="true">∫</mo><mrow><msup><mi>z</mi><mn>3</mn></msup><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo>𝑑</mo><mi>z</mi></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo maxsize="160%" minsize="160%">(</mo><mrow><mn>1</mn><mo>-</mo><mfrac><mrow><msup><mi>l</mi><mn>4</mn></msup><msup><mi>z</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><msup><mi>μ</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><msubsup><mi>r</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>2</mn></msubsup><mi>ln</mi><msup><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mfrac><mi>z</mi><msub><mi>r</mi><mo>+</mo></msub></mfrac><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mn>2</mn></msup></mrow><mrow><mn>4</mn><mo>⁢</mo><msup><mrow><mo maxsize="160%" minsize="160%">(</mo><mrow><mrow><msup><mi>κ</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>⁢</mo><msup><mi>μ</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mi>ln</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mfrac><mi>z</mi><msub><mi>r</mi><mo>+</mo></msub></mfrac><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>+</mo><mrow><msubsup><mi>r</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>2</mn></msubsup><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><mn>1</mn><mo>-</mo><msup><mi>z</mi><mn>2</mn></msup></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo maxsize="160%" minsize="160%">)</mo></mrow><mn>2</mn></msup></mrow></mfrac></mrow><mo maxsize="160%" minsize="160%">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow></mrow></mrow></mrow></math>

prevtext: It is also easy to calculate the horizon $r_{+}$ as a function of other variables as:
mathml:
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E14.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="r_{+}\approx\frac{2\pi T_{0}}{\kappa^{2}(2C_{2}+C_{1}\mu)}\Big{[}\frac{2\delta%
\mu_{2}}{\mu-\mu_{0}}\Big{(}\frac{T}{T_{0}}-1\Big{)}-C_{1}\Big{]}." display="block"><mrow><mrow><msub><mi>r</mi><mo>+</mo></msub><mo>≈</mo><mrow><mfrac><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>⁢</mo><mi>π</mi><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mi>T</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></mrow><mrow><msup><mi>κ</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mi>C</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></mrow><mo>+</mo><mrow><msub><mi>C</mi><mn>1</mn></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mi>μ</mi></mrow></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mfrac><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo maxsize="160%" minsize="160%">[</mo><mrow><mrow><mfrac><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>⁢</mo><mi>δ</mi><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mi>μ</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></mrow><mrow><mi>μ</mi><mo>-</mo><msub><mi>μ</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></mrow></mfrac><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo maxsize="160%" minsize="160%">(</mo><mrow><mfrac><mi>T</mi><msub><mi>T</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></mfrac><mo>-</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow><mo maxsize="160%" minsize="160%">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>-</mo><msub><mi>C</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></mrow><mo maxsize="160%" minsize="160%">]</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>.</mo></mrow></math>
